div1.p: Dearest family - This is a dark & very rainy Friday afternoon - & I'm sitting by the window in the living room where I have a view of the muddy road & drowned appearance everywhere outside. Aunt Lizzie is somewhere in the house while down below in the basement wood is being chopped - That & the drip outside & the ticking of Aunt Lizzie's clock on the fireboard are the only sounds to be heard - Evelyn & Emily having gone for a walk down the road!
Since my last epistle of Monday night nothing of particular note has happened.

Monday evening - My good intentions of Friday failed you see & yesterday spent most of the time calling & then decided that if I waited till tonight I'd have your letter to comment on but alas none came - except a very nice one from Lida - Only two or three times have I
failed to hear from home on Monday during the whole time of my stay - Suppose it was held up somewhere along the line - as occasionally will happen.

Well going back over the happenings of the past week - Tuesday after a late session at school. I went for a walk with Stella & little Blanche Huff after a call there. In the evening Tom came for help with Latin & history. He is a great boy and an exceedingly nice one - fine
sisters - all in our school but the youngest and she is coming.

Wednesday Emma Maples and I tramped over the muddy road - getting back about dark - Emma had supper with us - & eventually stayed all night - She is such a dear girl - about eighteen. Told me that the Pi Phis had certainly done a lot for Gatlinburg & that the school just meant everything to her. She loves music so Evelyn played & sang most of the evening - We all helped more or less - I corrected two sets of history papers on the side meanwhile.

Thursday after school - help the various debaters with their subject of immigration - practice with the quartet - & finish showing them how to put together our school magazine. Then coming home I started up Pi Phi lane branching off to the little house where Harrison lives & finding him doing up the dishes & looking after the youngsters of which there are three. Two room cabin as usual - but such a nice big stone fireplace & grand fire - You find them in every house - no wonder they get in the habit of "settin'" Well I set awhile although the lady of the house was not home being on a visit at her mother's father's - I did not know she was gone however. He told me about capturing a still up in the Sugar Lands during vacation - From here I journeyed on up Baskins to Martha's & sat in the dusk over another big fire - She - her sister and old mother live
in a two room cabin. She has three little girls - all in school - does our washing you know. Had an awfully good time & stayed so long it was dark when I got home.
Friday after school I just didn't seem to have the energy to write or do much of anything & wound up by putting on a clean dress after a bath.

Dr. Massy blew in just as we had finished supper - and later Mr. Huff. They visited around the fire until about nine - they then Mr. H. took the doctor home with him. They have a good many business dealings together - lumber - The doctor loves to talk and got started on the churches & ministers
in the county. Too many of both altogether he says.

Saturday was a day of labor for us all as usual - & wound up washing my hair which always produces a cold spell and strong wind. The debate came off in the evening having been postponed from the night before because of the rain - Two of the girls & I were judges - not much of a crowd there as a "sing" was held upat the Forks of the River. Mr. Cresswell - Stella & Amber Ogle (a new boy just started in the 9th grade) were against immigration - Tom - Cora & Betty Russell for it - had helped the latter the most & really felt they did the best anyway - Mr C. made some perfectly wild remarks - Anyway
I put my influence on Tom's side & they got the decision. Sunday was the usual excitement of Sunday School - (I forgot to say that Evelyn went home with the doctor Sat. eve. - back in the morning) a "burial" followed Sunday School for which Abbie & I did not stay - Poor Emily had to as no one else was there who could play (piano) It began to snow & was quite cold - just the day for a brisk tramp - so put on my new green cap & sallied about three miles up Mill Creek to the Oakley family where I visited about an hour - such a nice family. We enjoyed it very much - (they & I) After dinner here I felt just like starting out again - so got Josie Trentham at the hotel & we went up Roaring Fork branching off to a little creek. I wanted to see Maud Clabo one of my girls who hasn't come back yet - another walk of about three miles - From here we went on to the Carr family's house about a quarter of a mile getting home just at dark in time for B.Y. After that Aunt Lizzie & I visited over the fire as Emily went to bed early - Today - Cora McCarter & I went up Little Dudley about 2 mi. to see Mattie McC. one of my girls who hasn't come back since Xmas but expects to tomorrow. Just live to go around & visit this way & hope the weather stays clear this week so I can. Will not wait so long again - With loads of love to you all as ever
